awd_titl_txt: Social, Behavioral, and Academic Linkages throughout the Undergraduate Experience
awd_abstract_narration:
The outcomes of higher education are a consequence of individuals' personality traits and many
dimensions of the university experience. The Caltech Cohort Study (CCS) will track the entire
undergraduate student body of the California Institute of Technology (Caltech) over several years. It
uses repeated, incentivized surveys to elicit behavioral proxies: risk aversion, strategic sophistication,
competitiveness, social behavior, etc. The results will be married with objective outcomes: academic,
social, and financial. The project will examine the evolution of attributes over college years, the
formation of social interactions, and ultimately how certain attributes interact to produce educational
outcomes. The CCS also serves as an ideal environment for answering fundamental questions about
the external validity of incentivized surveys and laboratory experiments.

The CCS has four unique features. First, Caltech's small size makes it possible to track nearly
the entire student body over time (90% of students completed the first three surveys). Second, the
survey design allows measurement of a large set of behavioral traits for each individual. Third,
the repeated nature of the study makes it possible to track the stability of these traits across time
with minimal selection bias. Fourth, the array of behavioral traits elicited can be tied to real-world
behaviors and outcomes. The combination of these elements should be invaluable for a large battery
of basic social science questions.

The proposed study has the potential to improve the educational process in US higher education.
Understanding what impacts social and scholastic outcomes will help design certain aspects of college
education aimed at increasing well-being and academic performance, as well as furthering gender and
racial equality.

The proposal focuses on three areas. First, the dataset's longitudinal nature will allow for a careful
inspection of the stability (or lack thereof) of a wide array of behavioral attributes. Second, the rich
data on different layers of interactions over time (social, academic, and geographic) combined with
the comprehensive set of elicited attributes will allow us to study network formation processes. Last,
the data can be cross-checked against Caltech's experimental laboratory data to examine the impacts
of selection into experiments as well as the differences in responses occurring in the lab and outside.
The survey will also allow for a comparison of responses across other platforms and populations.
Ultimately, the detailed longitudinal data that will be collected have the potential to uncover
predictors of academic outcomes (chosen major, grades, and graduation), and the channels affecting
the evolution of different traits.

por.por_cntn:
The grant has allowed me to collect data relating to various experimental population pools. Specifically, we have run the Caltech Cohort Study (CCS) survey on Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk) using close to 1000 participants. We also ran the survey using Survey Sampling International (SSI), which is a platform allowing experimentation on a representative sample of the U.S.population, using over 1000 participants. Last, we collected detailed institutional data on the Caltech students that are in our data set. In addition, the project suggested several new directions for looking at how linkages between individuals are formed as well asseveral new questions regarding experimental methodology.

Below I specify the outcomes from several studies I pursued under this grant.

Experimenting with Measurement Error: Techniques with Applications to the Caltech Cohort Study (joint with Ben Gillen and Erik Snowberg, published in Journal of Political Economy) In this paper, we developed statistical techniques for handling experimental measurement error. These techniques were applied to data from the CCS. In particular, items in the CCS replicate three classic experiments, through which we demonstrate that results change substantially when measurement error is accounted for. The main message of this paper is that failing to properly account for measurement error may cause a fieldwide bias leading scholars to identify "new" phenomena. 

Testing the Waters: Behavior across Participant Pools (joint with Erik Snowberg, published in The American Economic Review) In this paper, we leverage the data from the CCS survey run at Caltech, with SSI andMTurk data to address concerns about the external validity of experiments with student participants. Our results suggest that behavior in the student population offers bounds on behaviors in other populations, and correlations between behaviors are largely similar across samples. Furthermore, non-student samples exhibit higher measurement error. Adding historical lab participation data from the Social Science Experimental Laboratory (SSEL) at Caltech, we find a small set of attributes over which labparticipants differ from non-lab participants. Using an additional set of lab experiments at Caltech, we see no evidence of observer effects. This paper has been presented invarious universities (UCSD, Columbia, Maryland, etc.). It has also been presented inplenary talks in several conferences (Stony Brook Game Theory, Information and SocialEconomics Workshop at Caltech, FETS in Paris). This paper was covered in the American Economic Association's Research Highlights (https://www.aeaweb.org/research/lab-experiments-external-validity).

The Evolution of Friendships and Homophily (joint with Matthew O. Jackson, Stephen M. Nei, and Erik Snowberg) In this study we consider how the patterns of social and professional interactions evolve. The longitudinal nature of the CCS offers aunique opportunity to study the formation of networks. Indeed, since we observe connections over time, we can distinguish between initial selection of friends, and convergence of certain malleable traits across connected individuals. Furthermore, we can tie friendship profiles to academic outcomes such as GPA and choice of major. Our results suggest growing densities, increasing homophily, and decreasing turnover in both social and study networks over time. Professional study networks, however, exhibit weaker homophily than social networks. We also see a strong impact of connection patterns on outcomes. In particular, linked female students of different ethnicities exhibit the greatest increases in GPA. 

Statistical Discrimination and Affirmative Action in the Lab (joint with Ahrash Dianat and Federico Echenique, published in Games and Economic Behavior) The data generated by the CCS regarding attitudes toward gender and race induced me to study the effectiveness of affirmative action in various settings. In this paper, we study experimentally the impacts of affirmative-action policies. We induced statistical discrimination in simple firm-worker labor market interactions. We then introduced affirmative-action policies that varied in size andduration of a subsidy firms received for hiring discriminated workers. These different affirmative-action policies had nearly the same effect and eliminated discriminatoryhiring practices. However, once lifted, few positive effects remained and discrimination reverted to its initial levels. 

Who Cares More? Allocation with Diverse Preference Intensities (joint with Pietro Ortoleva and Evgenii Safonov) The CCS raises many questions about the optimal allocation of scarce resources: desirable university residences, spots in classes, etc. In general, services are often allocated to individuals who rank them similarly but differ in their preference intensities. We characterize optimal allocation rules in such settings. We show that first-best allocations may involve lotteries. Second-best allocations always involve lotteries and coincide with first-best allocations non-trivially. Last, second-best allocations may entail disposal of services. 

Paying to Match: Decentralized Markets with Information Frictions (joint with Marina Agranov, Ahrash Dianat, and Larry Samuelson) My work on the evolution of networks using the CCS raised fundamental questions on how individuals choose to link with one another. In this project, we look experimentally at simple matching markets in which individuals do not know at the outset the full characteristics of their potential mates.
